title: Europe Stocks Climb as U.S. Futures, Dollar Drift: Markets Wrap
text:
(Bloomberg) -- European shares rose while U.S. futures struggled for traction and Treasuries edged lower before key inflation data in the world’s largest economy.

Mining and banking shares led the European Stoxx 600 higher, along with U.K. equities. Contracts on the three main stock gauges in the U.S. drifted. In Asia, Japanese equities tumbled as a swathe of companies traded without the right to the next dividend payment. Stocks fell in Seoul and gained in Australia while a Shanghai benchmark was almost flat.

The offshore yuan nudged higher after one of the world’s top bond-index providers bucked expectations and left China out of a benchmark gauge. Treasury 10-year note yields held at about 1.7% and a gauge of the dollar stayed in a narrow range.

Risk sentiment remains unsettled after taking a hit on Thursday amid heightened political drama in Washington and reports that the U.S. is unlikely to extend a waiver allowing American firms to supply China’s Huawei Technologies. Attention now turns to a slew of economic data in the U.S., including the Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of inflation and personal spending.

“A favorable development on the trade front -- that would be the biggest catalyst at this point” to drive equities higher, Brian Jacobsen, multi-asset strategist at Wells Fargo Asset Management, told Bloomberg TV. “We seem to be just waiting and seeing” until the high-level U.S.-China talks next month, he said.

Elsewhere, the pound slipped and gilts climbed after Bank of England policy maker Michael Saunders said rate cuts may be needed even if there is a Brexit deal. West Texas oil futures steadied around $56 a barrel. Bitcoin held most of Thursday’s losses, having dropped for five consecutive sessions to just above the $8,000 mark.

Some key events to watch out for on Friday:

Core PCE -- the Fed’s preferred inflation measure -- is due Friday. The forecast is for 1.8%.

Here are the main moves in markets:

Stocks

Futures on the S&P 500 Index increased 0.1% as of 9:18 a.m. London time.The Stoxx Europe 600 Index gained 0.4%.The U.K.’s FTSE 100 Index jumped 0.8%.The MSCI Asia Pacific Index decreased 0.6%.The MSCI Emerging Market Index fell 0.4%.

Currencies

The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index was little changed.The euro was unchanged at $1.0921.The British pound decreased 0.3% to $1.229.The Japanese yen was little changed at 107.87 per dollar.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasuries gained one basis point to 1.71%.Germany’s 10-year yield increased less than one basis point to -0.58%.Britain’s 10-year yield fell three basis points to 0.491%.

Commodities

Gold declined 0.4% to $1,498.41 an ounce.West Texas Intermediate crude increased 0.1% to $56.45 a barrel.
